newsitem.title: USA: PRESS DIGEST - Wall Street Journal - Sept 26.
newsitem.headline: PRESS DIGEST - Wall Street Journal - Sept 26.

text.p: The U.S. Treasury Department said its new inflation-indexed bonds will be linked to the consumer price index, the Wall Street Journal reported Thursday.
* Dana Corp defeated the United Auto Workers (UAW) in a union-representation election at an axle-parts plant in Missouri.

* Chrysler Corp appears to be ready to match Ford Motor Co's pledge to maintain 95 percent of UAW's jobs, but General Motors Corp is sending signals that it cannot make a similar commitment without major exceptions.
* Loral Space & Communications Ltd agreed to acquire AT&T Corp's Skynet system for $712.5 million.
* Dial Corp plans to slash its consumer-products lineup in half, cut its workforce by 250 and take $50 million in charges.
* Sales of existing homes slipped 0.5 percent in August.
* West Coast longshoremen narrowly approved a three-year contract they previously rejected.
* British money manager Invesco Plc is in preliminary talks to acquire closely held AIM Management Group of Houston, Texas, in a deal that could approach $1.8 billion in value.
* Loewen Group's chief executive vowed to resist a takeover attempt by Service Corp International.
* Bond prices surged and stocks ended higher, a day after the Federal Reserve decided to leave interest rates alone.
* Silicon Graphics Inc said its quarterly profit will be "substantially below" Wall Street's expectations.
* Johnson Controls Inc plans to acquire an Australian auto-parts supplier and create a joint venture with a Beijing-based automotive parts maker as part of a broader plan to expand into Asia.

* Tag Heuer has good timing. The Swiss maker of luxury sports watches known for precision is hitting Wall Street with an initial public offering at a time when shares for other luxury-goods sellers are riding high. - Heard on the Street
* Bond prices rose for the third straight day as some investors who had been on the sidelines grew emboldened by the Federal Reserve's decision not to raise interest rates. - Credit Markets
